sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a precipitation reaction
message_1:
What is the standard enthalpy change for the precipitation reaction between silver nitrate (AgNO3) and sodium chloride (NaCl) to form solid silver chloride (AgCl) and aqueous sodium nitrate (NaNO3), given the balanced chemical equation:

AgNO3(aq) + NaCl(aq) → AgCl(s) + NaNO3(aq) 

Assume standard conditions (298 K and 1 atm) and use the following heat of formation values:

ΔHf°(AgNO3) = -123.5 kJ/mol
ΔHf°(NaCl) = -411.2 kJ/mol
ΔHf°(AgCl) = -127.0 kJ/mol
ΔHf°(NaNO3) = -466.9 kJ/mol
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change (ΔH°) for the precipitation reaction, we can use the following equation:

ΔH° = Σ ΔHf°(products) - Σ ΔHf°(reactants)

For the given reaction:

AgNO3(aq) + NaCl(aq) → AgCl(s) + NaNO3(aq)

ΔH° = [ΔHf°(AgCl) + ΔHf°(NaNO3)] - [ΔHf°(AgNO3) + ΔHf°(NaCl)]

Substitute the given heat of formation values:

ΔH° = [(-127.0 kJ/mol) + (-466.9 kJ/mol)] - [(-123.5 kJ/mol) + (-411.2 kJ/mol)]

ΔH° = (-593.9 kJ/mol) - (-534.7 kJ/mol)

ΔH° = -59.2 kJ/mol

The standard enthalpy change for the precipitation reaction between silver nitrate and sodium chloride is -59.2 kJ/mol.
